description: Since late 16th century, borrowed from Middle French essay, essai (“essay”), meaning coined by Montaigne in the same time, from the same words in earlier meanings 'experiment; assay; attempt', from Old French essay, essai, assay, assai, from Latin exagium (“weight; weighing, testing on the balance”), from exigere + -ium.

entries.meaning: (authorship) A written composition of moderate length, exploring a particular issue or subject.

examples: This was Lee's first essay in the kind of offensive-defensive strategy that was to become his hallmark.

entries.meaning: (philately, finance) A proposed design for a postage stamp or a banknote.

description: From Middle French essayer, essaier, from Old French essaiier, essayer, essaier, assaiier, assayer, assaier, from essay, essai, assay, assai (“attempt; assay; experiment”) as above.

verbs.description: essay (third-person singular simple present essays, present participle essaying, simple past and past participle essayed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move forth, as into battle.
